Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Auroral Electrojet Waves and Wave Heating
Award.AbstractNarration: One of the important effects of auroral precipitation at high latitudes is the production of waves and turbulence in the ionosphere. These dynamic variations can cause disruption and degradation of communication and navigation signals that pass through the ionosphere. Although ionospheric irregularities were discovered in the auroral zone more than 75 years ago, fundamental questions about the way that the waves propagate and saturate in a turbulent state persist. The purpose of this award is to investigate a particular kind of turbulence referred to as Farley-Buneman waves. The objective is to study the internal mechanics of these waves, their effects on the background ionospheric state, and the interpretation of coherent radar backscatter that can be received from them. The investigation has experimental, theoretical, and modeling aspects as well as strong educational underpinnings. The broad goal of the research is to elucidate the processes involved in generating ionospheric structure by magnetospheric forcing (from above), one of the two main themes highlighted by the 2013 Decadal Survey for Solar and Space Physics. Its emphasis on the multiscale connections between the background forcing available during disturbed conditions, the auroral instability and turbulence it creates, and the feedback on the mean ionospheric state constitutes a systems approach to this complex and highly coupled process. The proposed study will be carried out by faculty and students at Cornell University and the University of Alaska, Anchorage, and will involve experimental field work in Alaska. Experimental data will be interpreted in the context of results from the theoretical investigation. One component of that investigation involves the construction of a 3D hybrid fluid-kinetic model of Farley- Buneman waves capable of simulating the wave mechanics at small and intermediate scales. The second component involves the development of a mathematical model of Farley-Buneman waves and turbulence, including saturation effects, based on the formalism of stochastic differential equations (SDEs). The broader impact of this investigation is associated with the novelty of the tools that will be developed, which have applications outside research in the radar aurora. Radar imaging has tremendous potential as a means of performing discovery research in geospace but is computationally demanding and will see little application outside the current effort until it can be simplified and accelerated. Additional broader impact will come from undergraduate and graduate education in geospace and CEDAR science at Cornell and the University of Alaska.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a project to study a kind of plasma wave commonly found in the Earth's ionosphere at about 100 km altitude. The waves, known as Farley Buneman or modified two-stream waves, occur at all latitudes but are most intense in the auroral zone. They are important because they modify the temperature and conductivity of the ionosphere and may affect other processes including magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling. They have been known about since the earliest days of radio science, being detectable from the ground by radar. Nonetheless, some of their basic properties remain poorly understood.

The experimental component of the research centers around a VHF research radar we have deployed in Homer, Alaska, to observe the waves. The radar is a coherent scatter radar imager, capable of observing Doppler spectra in the three dimensions where the scattering takes place. The radar shares a common volume with an incoherent scatter radar in Fairbanks which can measure ionospheric state parameters. Sounding rockets launched from the Poker Flat Research Range also pass through the volume observed by our radar.

Our project produced three significant outcomes. The first was the construction of a model of the waves based on theoretical analysis, numerical computations, and some heuristics. The model predicts the shapes of the Doppler spectra measured by our radar in terms of the background driving electron convection speed and direction. The model is invertible, enabling us to estimate convection from the radar observations of the waves. This is significant since convection is perhaps the most important indicator of the state of the auroral ionosphere, particularly during disturbed conditions. The resolution of the convection estimates we find is of the order of a few km in space and a few secs. in time.

Another outcome of the project was a theoretical explanation of the behavior of the waves with a foundation more rigorous than linear theory combined with heuristics. The new theory considers fluctuations in the behavior of Farley Buneman waves. Conventionally, one might study wave evolution under different sets of fluctuations, combining the results in an ensemble average to gauge the fluctuation's effects. Instead, using the formalism of stochastic differential equations, we derived the dynamic equations that describe how the ensemble average itself evolves, directly. The theory predicted how waves propagate and saturate at a phase speed close to the ion sound speed, properly defined. The theory was tested against simulation results from a particle-in-cell simulation of the waves performed by colleagues.

Finally, we sought to develop a numerical simulation of our own capable of reproducing the results of the aforementioned PIC simulations only with less computational cost. We developed a hybrid fluid/kinetic (Vlasov) simulation which can be run on a small server (as opposed to a large cluster). The simulation architecture is novel and should serve as a template for other investigators in the field to follow. The simulation is presently being validated and tested.

In the course of performing this research, we used the Homer radar to support complementary research projects taking place in the region. We supported sounding rocket experiments from the PFRR as well as ionospheric modification experiments at the nearby HAARP facility in Gakona. HAARP is able to generate plasma waves that are, in some respects, like the waves that are the focus of this project. In studying the heater-induced waves, we can draw conclusions about the behavior of the plasma waves found in nature.
